title: Destiny of `publish --missing`

labels.name: question
labels.description: Issue asks a question rather than reporting a problem

body:
I was trying to get myself to like what `publish --missing` aims to do, but I keep failing on that. All it can to is nothing (`skip`), or call `create_sibling` (`inherit`). It fails for any other kind of remote, and of course cannot do anything if a superdataset has nothing in common with a subdataset in terms of  remotes.

That all comes at the price of an API argument slot, and a TODO list that nobody has tackled: #1344, #1491, #1673 in two years.

I am not convinced that mixing tasks (push content vs. create publication targets) is anyhow superior to a dedicated command whose purpose is to create publication targets for datasets that don't have one. It certainly runs counter to my desire to come up with a reasonably minimal core API.

Another aspect is the implied dependency of `publish` on `create_sibling`. Taking one step back, I'd  consider `create_sibling` as more of a leaf command, as there are plenty of publications targets that have nothing to do with this functionality (all kinds of web/storage services) and even within the Git world (GitHub, GitLab) `create_sibling` is pretty much irrelevant.

Taken all together, I think we should not fold `create_sibling` functionality into `publish`.
